Author: rgvtim

Comment: I’m posting this article, and I’m also posting this from the Homeland Security website, because of the below which does NOT state that an end date to the traveling domestically part bolded below:  **EDITED TO ADD:** I am not trying to convince you not to get it. But, some are freaking out that they need to fly domestically and don't have their card yet, etc.  [https://www.dhs.gov/real-id/real-id-faqs](https://www.dhs.gov/real-id/real-id-faqs)  "Beginning May 7, 2025 every state and territory resident will need to present a REAL ID compliant license/ID, or another acceptable form of identification, for accessing federal facilities, entering nuclear power plants, and boarding commercial aircraft. **The card, itself, must be REAL ID compliant unless the resident is using an alternative acceptable document such as a passport or passport card, or state-issued Enhanced Driver’s License.** The Act does not require individuals to present identification where it is not currently required to access a federal facility (such as to enter the public areas of the Smithsonian) nor does it prohibit an agency from accepting other forms of identity documents (such as a U.S. passport or passport card).  If you are traveling internationally you will still need your passport. **If you are traveling domestically, you will only need one valid form of identification – either your REAL ID or another acceptable alternative such as a passport, not both."**  No. REAL ID cards cannot be used for border crossings into Canada, Mexico or other international travel."

Comment: I got the Real ID last time I renewed my driver's license, but what is the point of the whole thing? I totally do not get it. How am I a more reliable, more authentic citizen with this card? I can't believe how much money and time have been wasted on this weird program.

Part of the Real ID process requires making sure that Social Security information and State information matches. I'm a trans woman who was unable to get Social Security information changed in time before Rubio banned any changes due to gender so I cannot get a Real ID due to the mismatch and thus, can't get on an airplane. This is clearly targeting marginalized groups and removing our freedom to travel.

Beginning May 7, 2025 every state and territory resident will need to present a REAL ID compliant license/ID, or another acceptable form of identification, for accessing federal facilities, entering nuclear power plants, and boarding commercial aircraft. **The card, itself, must be REAL ID compliant unless the resident is using an alternative acceptable document such as a passport or passport card, or state-issued Enhanced Driver’s License.** The Act does not require individuals to present identification where it is not currently required to access a federal facility (such as to enter the public areas of the Smithsonian) nor does it prohibit an agency from accepting other forms of identity documents (such as a U.S. passport or passport card). Comment: Thank you. It can also take additional steps and $ for women who use their married name but didn’t change their social security card. I was one of them, and needed to show first marriage certificate (notarized) for a marriage that was over 25 years ago, divorce decree, and 2nd marriage certificate for current marriage. Shoulda just kept my maiden name.  I had the last two items but not the first, as that marriage was so long ago and to me was simply irrelevant.   Now imagine (as I’m sure you don’t have to!!!) if you changed your gender or name.   Or imagine if your courthouse from a pre-digital marriage burned down, and all records were lost, which happened with my divorce decree. I did eventually get a copy but it took major hoops, money, and time. (to clarify I needed it about ten years ago not for real ID but to qualify for a mortgage…. Funny thing is my current husband is also divorced and mortgage company didn’t care to see his divorce decree…..)

Author: florapocalypse7

Comment: I'm a trans ally and realize you're just used to being targeted every which way right now, but this has nothing to do with trans people. This policy was originally put in place as a recommendation of the 9/11 Commission Report.  The US is the only country among its peers that do not have a national ID system of some kind where there are reasonable controls to ensure the ID isn't fake and that the person's identity is legitimate.  This has been delayed for years because having this basic assurance on the trustworthiness of government-issued IDs has been quite expensive and slow since it has forced most state govts to fully modernize their DMV systems while suffering budget cuts.
